Hi Abhishek, Brian.

Thanks for the feedback.

To explain the motivation a bit more: we are running this patch/implementation of the spec in our production for about a year now. The use-case is large Windows images that are migrated from another platform. Image sizes reach hundreds of gigabytes and take many hours to upload to our Swift, so we were looking for ways to speed it up and found that using at least 2 threads helps a lot here.

We are happy to rebase and resubmit the spec and the patches. We could also set the default pool size to be "1" which effectively is not changing anything and let Openstack operators decide on the setting that works best for their particular Glance setup.

What do you think?

I think this will be a swift specific change and will not have impact on other glance backends,and as you are proposing to maintain default behavior I am ok with it. While you resubmit the spec, please answer to comments given by Brian.
Ack,restoring the patch so that we can discuss this for upcoming cycle!

What if any other exception is raised? Even the newly added code can raise InvalidGroupSnapshot, not to mention the other functions that are called from _get_infinidat_sg().

Hello Pete,

Thank you very much for the review!

>> What if any other exception is raised?
>> Even the newly added code can raise InvalidGroupSnapshot,
>> not to mention the other functions that are called from _get_infinidat_sg().

We should ignore only one error - "GroupSnapshotNotFound"
(if the given snapshot does not exist - i.e. already deleted).
And we should fail in any other cases. For example:

_get_infinidat_sg() can raise:
- GroupSnapshotNotFound (if no snapshot found - i.e. already deleted). And we should ignore this error.
- InvalidGroupSnapshot (if the given dataset is not a snapshot). We should fail and propagate it.
- some other unexpected exceptions in case of external failures. We should fail and propagate it.

_get_infinidat_sg() was added to simplify (move some common code to a separate function, like a _get_infinidat_pool, _get_infinidat_cg) and contains exactly the same code as the previous code. The main functional change is for _create_volume() to get into the account the "volume.group_id" value.

Thank you!

Added comment for the error code CMMVC5804E. Returning None when the volumegroup-snapshot or the volumegroup specified in the command does not exists in SVC storage.

Below is the usecase for returning None:
When volumegroup-snapshot is deleted directly from storage then the entry will be still present in cinder. To handle this scenario, I am returning None and giving a INFO message in the logs as : 'Tried to delete non-existent volumegroup snapshot' and proceeding to remove the entry from cinder.

This scenario is same for lsvdisk command as well. Returning None when the volume does not exists in the SVC storage. https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/storwize_svc_common.py#L619

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Ugh, these shard_range cache metrics have gotten a little messy - let's clear up what we want before we do tests:

I don't like counting skips in one metric and the skips.status_int in another - if you want the total skips it should just be a sum over all the skips.status_int

then we should have some symmetry for the miss.status_int

then hit I guess is just it's own thing that never has status_int (except maybe for container_info where I guess we could report on what was in memcache!?)
thanks for the view.

I feel it's okay to do counting skips and misses in separate metrics. It's logically clear when we maintain two different dimensions of metrics (shard_updating.cache and shard_updating.backend), versus mixing them up together?

IIUC we currently have:

  shard_<op>.cache.[hit|miss|skip]
  shard_<op>.backend.<status_int>

where op is 'listing' or 'updating'

and the goal *might* be to have:

  shard_<op>.cache.[hit|miss|skip|force_skip]
  shard_<op>.backend.[miss|skip|force_skip|disabled].<status_int>

but the patch currently gives us:

  shard_<op>.cache.[hit|miss|skip|force_update]
  shard_<op>.backend.[skip|force_update].<status_int>
  shard_<op>.backend.<status_int>
i think your intuition to concretize the metrics pattern with a re-usable method is spot on!  Can you keep going - or do we need to talk with Tim/Al and figure out better what we want?
thanks a lot for the review.
if there is some incompatibility with current metrics then that should be documented in the commit message
yeah, since this direction won't be compatible with current metrics, let's wait for opinions from Tim/Al.

In the document mentioned in the commit message, i see that the current syntax that is being used is "name @ url" replacing "egg=" format.

So in the document change shouldn't it be like the following ? -
os-brick@URL
cinder@URL
Awesome. Thanks for the clarification. +1

Good question.  The reason for using url#egg=name or name@url is when the package name isn't included in the url.  So for example, 

  git+https://github.com/some-org/some-repo#egg=foo

the package name we want to reference is 'foo', but the repo name is 'some-repo'.  So in that case, we would need to use the preferred PEP 509 syntax of

  foo@git+https://github.com/some-org/some-repo
  
But in our case, we have the package name and the repo name the same:

  git+https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder#egg=cinder
  
So we can just use the normal git url without specifying an extra name.
Not an expert on this but we are clearly not using egg as it's intended to be used so we shouldn't be affected by removing it. LGTM.
Thanks for the clarification on the usage. +1
Useful!

we can attempt to harden nova for in advertent restart due to an error in libvirt and systemd startign it again via a restart poicly or socket activation but operators should be aware that if they intentionlly restart libvirt while vms are migrating the should expect it to break nova.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
there is a specific edgecase that im considerign namely that if we have entered the post copy phase we must not attempt to roolback.

nova only allow live migrtation to rollback while the vm is still running on the source host if there are any failure on the dest host we must not attempt to rollback.

so if libvirt is restarted durign postcopy nova must not attempt to revert.

We will want to have test coverage for this change to assert that the volume is not formatted for a NFS volume.

Would also like to have a code comment explaining why (because NFS uses LUKS inside qcow2 instead of raw LUKS) we will exclude NFS volume.
NFS uses LUKS inside qcow2 in order to create snapshots

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
There's some subtlety here not mentioned in the commit message -- is_luks() returns false for the NFS case, because NFS is using LUKS inside of qcow2 and not regular LUKS.

This means that this detection isn't the right check in that case (and neither is the _format_volume() call below).

Oh, I had thought encrypted NFS would always return is_luks_inside_qcow2 = True.

If not, then I guess there is no way around other than checking the protocol.

Something I want to make sure I understand, if the NFS volume is supposed to be encrypted but does not identify as luks inside qcow2, that means it does not need to be formatted in any way and it will work fine?

Are there any other protocols that should be handled the same way that we should add to the check? Would also be nice to include a code comment explaining why not NFS to help ppl reading the code later on.

> Something I want to make sure I understand, if the NFS volume is supposed to be encrypted but does not identify as luks inside qcow2, that means it does not need to be formatted in any way and it will work fine?

Sorry if I wasn't clear enough in the commit message. NFS volume is supposed to be encrypted but does identify as luks inside qcow2. Cinder already formats it. 

> Are there any other protocols that should be handled the same way that we should add to the check? Would also be nice to include a code comment explaining why not NFS to help ppl reading the code later on.

There are no qcow2 block devices so far, but in the future there may be others, but so far only NFS.
As far as I understand NFS will be the only case. We are still looking for the corner cases. However, adding is_luks_inside_qcow2  looks like the right approach to me.

> As far as I understand NFS will be the only case. We are still looking for the corner cases. However, adding is_luks_inside_qcow2  looks like the right approach to me. 

OK, cool.

Adding is_luks_inside_qcow2 unfortunately will not work for this scenario where we are deciding whether to format the volume in this manner, because the NFS volume apparently will or can also be missing encryption headers when we get  here.

I'm unsure about a corner case here -- if is_luks and is_luks_inside_qcow2 both return False, presumably it isn't correct to call _format_volume() at line 2066 for the NFS case?  (Which would create a LUKS-formatted file instead of LUKS inside qcow2.)

templates/openidc.conf.erb.message: Yeah, defining more than one OIDCRedirectURI seems definitely problematic.

My understanding is that this should point the location protected with openid-connect auth, and the previous value looks correct to me.

The keystone guide suggests using separate uris for keystone auth and websso but currently we use the single /sso uri for both.

If the current value does not work then the appropriate step would be to use /auth and add the location entity to put openid-connect auth over that uri, as is described in the guide.

Hi Takashi, thanks for taking the time to review my changes.

So the idea is that I add a new location directive like:

  <Location /v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/keycloak/protocols/openid/auth>
      Require valid-user
      AuthType openid-connect
  </Location>

hooks/ceph_hooks.py.message:
This algorithm is based on the one in ceph-ansible[0].  The discussion on the bug report suggests we want to aim for something a bit more sophisticated, hence the WIP tag here.  Will update once we've come to some conclusion about it.

Also, not sure why it's dividing by number of OSDs here - I don't completely understand what the osd memory target option does, and can't find docs yet.  Please let me know if there's somewhere I can find more context on this. :)


[0]: https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/blob/c878e99589bde0eecb8ac72a7ec8bc1f66403eeb/roles/ceph-config/templates/ceph.conf.j2#L103

I am not sure what 20% signifies in any case ;-)
But as Nobuto Murata said, the logic needs tweak in any case. It'd look like:
```
osd_memory_target = (total_ram * 0.7) / num_osds
```
to follow cephadm's logic of using 70% of host memory for OSDs.

In addition, I think this needs:

1. A lower bound check: If the calculated osd_memory_target is less than 4G, it's probably best to issue a warning and default to 4G. This is the minimum recommended (hence upstream default of 4G).

2. Provide the ability to set the actual % to be used for osd_memory_target (i.e. allow specifying a value or 'auto'). The default of 70% would work well dedicated storage hosts. But in a hyperconverged environment, it's better to let it configurable by the user/admin because they want to use less memory (not 70%) for OSDs if there are other services which dominate the system load. Obviously this would require an upper bound check as well - in case user specifies 100% or more of the host memory (accidentally or otherwise).
Ok, the implementation now should cover all these points :)

It's per OSD memory target. If it's set as 20% for exmaple with 10 OSDs/drives, then the target will end up with 200% of memory consumption of the host :-)

[from the bug comment]
> As stated in the bug description, cephadm has a logic trying to use 70% of host memory with OSDs. We could have a similar option and suggest setting 70% (but with an empty value for backward compatibility).
> https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/cephadm/services/osd/#automatically-tuning-osd-memory
> https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/08718ae283f6a62612c74b10d5da7efd2ea5f896/src/pybind/mgr/cephadm/serve.py#L172

specs/2023.1/approved/glance/new-locatio.message:
I think it would be good here to describe how the new scheme addresses all the old use cases, something like this:

  This is done in order to prevent malicious
  users from modifying the image location again and again since the location
  added for the first time is the correct one as far as Glance is concerned.

  When multiple image locations were added, Glance had only a single image
  store.  Since Train, Glance has  multiple stores, and we have added API
  calls that allow users to manipulate data locality with respect to store.
  Further, a store is an opaque identifier, whereas an image location
  exposes backend details that users don't need to know.

  Here are the current use cases for the direct manipulation of image
  locations along with an explanation of how they can be handled by the
  new Location API.

  1. When using a copy-on-write (COW) backend shared by Nova and Glance,
     Nova can create an image record in Glance, snapshot a server image
     directly in the backend, and set the location on the image record.

     This use case is covered by the new add-location call, and having
     its default policy be image owner or service.

  2. A user wants to have a single image record, but have image data
     stored in multiple locations for locality (i.e., to have image
     data as close as possible to where it's consumed).

     This use case is handled by the glance multiple stores feature
     plus image import, which since API v2.8, allows a 'stores' parameter
     specifying where the image data should be stored.  This applies to both
     newly created images and existing images (via the copy-image import
     method).

     In this workflow, Glance itself manipulates the image locations; there
     is no need for the user to interact with locations directly.

  3. An operator wants to introduce a new storage backend and decommission
     the current backend while keeping the same image catalog.

     Similar to #2, this can be handled by using the copy-image import
     method and the delete-image-from-store API call introduced in v2.10.
Thanks Brian, this was elaborate and helpful, updated it.

I guess I lost focus during the PTG discussion, because I don't remember this at all.  I have four concerns here:

1. First the stupid concern, namely people seem to think 'checksum'==md5 (and historically, that has been true in Glance).  So let's call this parameter something like "do_secure_hash" or "compute_os_hash_value" so people don't freak out.

2. If this is an HTTP Store issue, we already allow users to set "validation data" when adding a location [0, 1].  Why don't we do that instead of do_checksum (where I presume Glance would download the data, compute the checksum, and then store it)?

3. What happens when '"do_checksum": true' for other stores?  What's the behavior?

4. Following #2, are we going to allow the caller to set validation_data with the new add-locations API?  I suspect we should.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance-specs/+/597648
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/597368
Done

Since i heard about the HTTP store issue for the first time during PTG and I don't have much idea about the HTTP store itself, I will answer the concerns with superficial knowledge but Erno suggested the change and can answer things better.

1) I don't mind changing the name since there was None suggested during PTG. "do_secure_hash" sounds good since people might confuse "compute*" with nova compute.

2) I also have the same idea that glance will compute the hash values based on this parameter and assumed HTTP store is not capable of doing it. Even i couldn't find the checksum or hash value being computed in the http store[1].
I think the idea of "validation data" is when a store provides hash information then we add it to the image right? If that's the case then maybe http store is not capable of computing it so assigning the task to glance for it.
Having said that, I'm not super familiar with this so I think Erno can answer better as he suggested this approach.

3) I don't think we will modify other stores to pass this parameter and I'm unsure if other stores even call the locations API or it is handled internally.

4) Same as #2, I'm unsure about it and the glance team can suggest better on this.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance_store/blob/0df64d5af92b46457fd3f13aceb69b4f94b8b53c/glance_store/_drivers/http.py

Yes the point was that the user does not need to go and download the image on their laptop and calculate it's needed hash to be able to get usable image out of it. Glance is perfectly capable of calcuating the hash upon image upolad (say web-download), so it should be able to calculate the hash on location create as well. Like everything, this should be store agnostic and there is no reason to artificially imit it to http-store only. That was just an exampe of the usecase.

What comes to #4 we should alow it in my opinion and if both are provided (the vaidation data and "do_secure_hash" we shoud reject the image data if these two does not match.

I think you want a JSON boolean here, not a string, so

  "do_checksum": false,

Correct, it's not useful here so removed.

I suggest rewriting this section to say something like this:

  No worse than it is now, and possibly better.

  1. The get-locations policy is restricted to the 'service' role,
     so users will not be able to see image locations.  Thus with
     'show_multiple_locations' and 'show_direct_url' set to False,
     the new get-locations API will not expose location information
     to users.

  2. The add-location policy is restricted by default to
     image-owner-or-service.  This will allow end users to add a
     location to an image to address current uses of this functionality
     that we aren't aware of.  Even allowing this, the data-substitution
     attack is blocked because the API call will only be allowed for an
     image in 'queued' status.  The add-location API cannot be used to
     add a location to an 'active' image and then delete the original
     location, so the OSSN-0065 attack is not possible under this
     scenario.

     Further, the add-locations call (unlike the current method of
     updating locations via PATCH), does not require the locations to
     be visible to succeed.  Thus operators will be able to configure
     Glance with 'show_multiple_locations' and 'show_direct_url' set
     to False, even when other services are sharing a COW backend with
     Glance and the operator wants an optimized workflow.

Am I correct in that this patch assumes that all Ceph devices reside in `/dev/` ? If so, this patch is insufficient, as we support block devices from any source, as long as they are usable.

Furthermore, I'm not 100% on board with the idea of having apparmor be enforced by default, given that it can be disruptive to deploy an OSD with such a configuration in an already running cluster, as it needs manual restarting of services.
ACK. After talking with Alexander, we agreed that an additional doc change is sufficient to point out the details regarding devices.

> Am I correct in that this patch assumes that all Ceph devices reside in /dev/  ? If so, this patch is insufficient, as we support block devices from any source, as long as they are usable.

I'm a little worried about these assertions -- I don't think there's a guarantee that the return will advance between calls to time.time():

 >>> for x in itertools.count():
 ...     if time.time() >= time.time():
 ...         break
 ... 
 >>> x
 2
 >>> for x in itertools.count():
 ...     if time.time() >= time.time():
 ...         break
 ... 
 >>> x
 12
 >>> for x in itertools.count():
 ...     if time.time() >= time.time():
 ...         break
 ... 
 >>> x
 27

Probably better to mock out time to ensure it advances.

actually, the call of "timing_since" is required to pass "start_time". So for below assertions, even time.time() won't advance, mock_cache.args[1] (which is the start_time) still will be > 0.
self.assertTrue(mock_cache.args[1] > 0)

But it's good to have mock of time to check the args precisely.

Here the test should be if the loader_element text filename contains "secboot".

Then after https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/sushy-tools/+/842266 add the check for secure attribute yes/no
I think setting should only be supported after https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/sushy-tools/+/842266 so the config doesn't actually have to track OVMF file paths

This link seems to be broken or outdated.

It looks like this one is correct as for today:
https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#operating-system-booting

And it seems that what are we looking for, is "loader" element with attribute "secure='yes'"
You need to be checking the nvram path, not the loader path. "secboot" in the loader path does not mean that secure boot is enabled.

Sorry guys I can't get how nvram refers to the secure boot. From the link above:

> nvram
Some UEFI firmwares may want to use a non-volatile memory to store some variables. In the host, this is represented as a file and the absolute path to the file is stored in this element. Moreover, when the domain is started up libvirt copies so called master NVRAM store file defined in qemu.conf. If needed, the template attribute can be used to per domain override map of master NVRAM stores from the config file. Note, that for transient domains if the NVRAM file has been created by libvirt it is left behind and it is management application's responsibility to save and remove file (if needed to be persistent). Since 1.2.8

And at the same time:

> loader
The optional loader tag refers to a firmware blob, which is specified by absolute path, used to assist the domain creation process. It is used by Xen fully virtualized domains as well as setting the QEMU BIOS file path for QEMU/KVM domains. Xen since 0.1.0, QEMU/KVM since 0.9.12 Then, since 1.2.8 it's possible for the element to have two optional attributes: readonly (accepted values are yes and no) to reflect the fact that the image should be writable or read-only. The second attribute type accepts values rom and pflash. It tells the hypervisor where in the guest memory the file should be mapped. For instance, if the loader path points to an UEFI image, type should be pflash. Moreover, some firmwares may implement the Secure boot feature. Attribute secure can be used to tell the hypervisor that the firmware is capable of Secure Boot feature. It cannot be used to enable or disable the feature itself in the firmware. Since 2.1.0
OK I think I get it now. A firmware which supports secure boot might also boot in non-secure mode. nvram determines the mode, and the specific keys etc set up for secure boot behaviour.

I've just tried various combinations of firmware/nvram, secboot and not on my Fedora-35.

My findings align with Dmitry's experience, and contradicts the above documentation somewhat. Here is the output of "mokutil --sb-state" after booting each:

OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd + OVMF_VARS.secboot.fd = SecureBoot enabled
OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd + OVMF_VARS.fd = SecureBoot disabled
OVMF_CODE.fd + OVMF_VARS.secboot.fd = This system doesn't support Secure Boot
OVMF_CODE.fd + OVMF_VARS.fd = This system doesn't support Secure Boot

According to this, we can always use OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd and toggle secure boot with OVMF_VARS.fd/OVMF_VARS.secboot.fd. I even managed to get an existing domain to switch by changing the template="" and deleting the nvram before rebooting. I'll rework [1] to do this.

Unfortunately <os firmware="efi"> will only ever deploy a full secure-boot combination and doesn't allow the nvram to be overridden, so I'm going to need to drop the approach in [2] until libvirt provide some automatic mechanism to select uefi-but-not-secure 😞

etc/kayobe/environments/myenv/kolla/inventory/../..

The name of the directory is the environment. In the base configuration this looks like:

etc/kayobe/kolla/inventory/../..

yielding 'kayobe'. We needed to have a name for this inventory from the base layer and kayobe didn't seem like a bad name.

kubernetes/kubernetes-unversioned/debian.message:
This needs to remove just the 'RemoveSelfLink=false' from the string, not the entire line. If you add a custom feature-gate as an override (as described in the LP), then that customization needs to be retained also.

Might be able to do something similar to the function below, which uses the sed regular expression buffer to as part of the replacement .
Chris actually had submitted recent code that does the same thing in Python, I'll see if I can find that reference.

eg.,
    sed -i \
    's/^\( *\)feature-gates:\s.*RemoveSelfLink=false/\1feature-gates: RemoveSelfLink=false/g' \
    "${KUBEADM_CONFIGMAP_TMPFILE}"

This keeps a portion of the line in parentheses () and then puts it back as \1 and then adds back only what we wanted changed. This is kind of tricky, we also have to handle comma-separated-values for this string.

This class is extracted from ShardRange.

IIRC there's places where we abuse ShardRange when we only need something as basic as a Namespace, so this could prove a useful extraction in itself.

In this patch, when it store cache blobs, serialize() calls "__iter__" which contains both lower and upper. Is it still a concern which shard range namespaces may contain gap? maybe that's why you still kept upper?

I accepted Tim's argument that if there is a gap then we have to send the update somewhere, so sending to the adjacent range is OK.

The lower, upper and name are both written out for the containing NamespaceMap range, but only the lower and name are written for each contained namespace - see the _serialize method and test_store_in_memcache in test_utils.py:

        self.assertEqual({'leaf': False,
                          'lower': '',
                          'name': 'shard-updating-v2/a/c/',

                                    ['d', 'shard-updating-v2/a/c/[1]']],
                          'upper': ''},
                         fake_memcache.store['shard-updating-v2/a/c/'])
        self.assertEqual({'leaf': True,
                          'lower': '',
                          'name': 'shard-updating-v2/a/c/[0]',
                          'items': [['', 'range-0'],
                                    ['b', 'range-1']],
                          'upper': 'd'},
                         fake_memcache.store['shard-updating-v2/a/c/[0]'])
        self.assertEqual({'leaf': True,
                          'lower': 'd',
                          'name': 'shard-updating-v2/a/c/[1]',
                          'items': [['d', 'range-2'],
                                    [u'\N{SNOWMAN}', 'range-3']],

                         fake_memcache.store['shard-updating-v2/a/c/[1]'])

OK, so when we say we deepen this into a tree, it remains a very flat tree, like the shard ranges? or at every leaf, can we build it up with new namespaces and then turn and then deepen that?

  t0:  shards-updating-v2/a/c/ -|- [0]
                                |- [1] 
                                |- [2]
                             
  t1:  shards-updating-v2/a/c/ -|- [0]
                                |- [1] -|-[3]
                                |       |-[4]
                                |- [2]

So when we have thousands of potentual leaves, we are sharding them out the tree?

Just attempting to load up the plan in my head.

Currently just one level of depth in the tree. I have resisted making deepen() recursive: more levels means more memcache calls, and I figure that one level makes a big difference to the blob sizes. For example, if we use 500 shard ranges per blob, then containers with ~5000 shard ranges (so maybe 5 billion objects) have a 10x reduction in blob size (and that's without the added benefit of more compact serialisation), and that's with just 10 items in the top level. We'd need to grow to 250000 shard ranges before getting 500 items at the top level, at which point we might want to think about adding another level to the tree.

So if we did the extra work and testing to write recursion into deepen(), I'm not sure we'd use it (unless we wanted really small blobs).

At the same time I tried to allow for more levels in the future e.g. by naming the leaves using [n] suffix so the next layer can be names with [n][m] suffixes etc. In fact, I think the recursion could be added right now ... BUT its more work, more tests, more review.

calls will fail unless they explicitly specify that the microversion they want is 1.0.  This is despite the fact that more likely than not, they are not using secret consumers - and so would probably be just fine.

This breaking behavior will be repeated every time we increment the client version.

In the previous patch, if the server did not support the requested microversion, we ended up negotiating the best version that the server did support - and warned the user accordingly.  While not as clean, it might provide for a better user experience and also allow us more flexibility to make changes without worrying about breaking changes.
This should be addressed now with the changes in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-barbicanclient/+/870077/11

which is defined here:

I'm channeling the Zen of Python here.  Specifically: "Simple is better than complex."

The annotation framework in earlier versions of this patch chain is a nice use of metaprogramming, and it could be useful if we get into a situation where we're having to support lots of microvesrions at once.  For the purposes of implementing secret consumers though, we can the same result from this (and the below) if statements.

If we find ourselves adding more microversions in the future then we can reconsider the multimethod approach, but I think this is good enough for now.

I also appreciate that there is the not-so-secret agenda of ultimately deprecating this client for the openstack SDK, so that adding less complexity is better.

Thanks for the review. I agree on most of these points.

The shelf unload issue isn't a typo and isn't as cut and dry as it seems. Looking at the docs[1], it seems both are used. shelveOffload is the name of the action in the api, but the action is referred to as Shelf-Offload. I leaned towards shelf-offload since it makes more grammatical sense (to unload from the shelf). I understand the argument for using either name and honestly wouldn't lose any sleep whichever way we went. Just explaining my rationale.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=shelf-offload-remove-server-shelveoffload-action-detail#shelf-offload-remove-server-shelveoffload-action

[2] https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/shelf

This failing during service creation because the AZ already exists and we're not rolling back properly. Guess we're missing unit test coverage to say I didn't spot this locally 😞

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/dcaa00b0d5a546ffa02126088a5d6866/log/controller/logs/screen-m-dat.txt#445
This turned out to be easier to resolve than expected, though I got caught out by issues with the tests. See the revised commit message for more context.

btw, the reason for this is because you can't have a function decorated with context manager call another decorated function. The decorator isn't clever enough (whether that's intentional or not I don't know) to realise we already have an existing session that should be re-used. You'll see this pattern throughout. The other pattern you'll see is private functions that optionally use a session argument. This allows us to call these from both migrated and (currently) non-migrated functions. Where this happens, I attempt to call them out with TODOs. Hope this helps! 🤓

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: IIUC the monkey patching only applies to dnspython>=2 at least. Either we need to make it conditional or amend our requirements accordingly.

Hmm, interesting point.
This class has existed since 2.0.0, but just wasn't used for validation until 2.3.0.
This patch is also compatible with 1.16.0 (in the requirements.txt), but it just won't be used for anything (the enum was just a list of constants in 1.16.0).
So, it doesn't introduce a version compatibility issue as far as I can see.
If you still think we should make a chance for this, propose something for me.
Ah, right. We still might want to bump our dnspython req to >=2.0, in particular since we don't test the 1.x version anymore, but that can be done independently.
This is a place we have to go, the multipools probably won't work on a 1.16.0 version which is in the requirement.txt do to its event handling changes.

This patch has two positive reviews, including a core reviewer.
As this fixes compatibility with a dependency and passes the Designate tempest suite, I am going to workflow this patch.

Tox extra args are not necessarily posargs. They may be other flags. You need to embed the -- in tox extra args if what you are passing is posargs.

I'm confused as to the approach; can't you just reconfigure the BMC to enable IPMI over LAN if it's disabled? Why would you still prefer the IPMI methods for older firmwares? (Just to avoid behavior change?)
Thanks for review!

Regarding new version of firmware:
Server firmware team wants to discourage use of IPMI because they think IPMI is less secure compared to HTTPS. Incompatibility introduced in new version of firmware is representation of such discouragement. So I would like to use HTTPS instead of IPMI.

Regarding old version of firmware:
Reason why I continue to use IPMI on old firmware version is (as you said) to avoid behavior change of existing user.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I'd almost prefer that instead of trying to handle the version and make decisions based upon that, that we take a "does this work? yes/no, okay, that didn't work, what about this? yes/no, okay, the other two didn't work, lets try this last possible option.

I agree with FJ Hardware Engineering, IPMI is basically insecure and highly problematic and we (the community) should not be encouraging or requiring IPMI usage. Adding a bunch of version detection logic and forked logic based upon version just seems problematic and painful where as we can try/fallback appropriately based upon the situation.

I'll note that upon further consideration, the version tracking method used here is not really going to be backportable for multiple reasons.

Please switch to a try/fallback model if you want a patch that is more likely to be backportable.

Julia and JayF
Thanks for review.

I have one concern on try/fallback model. If I follow this model, iRMC driver first tries IPMI, and if IPMI fails it tries Redfish.
In this case, IPMI operation is done through code in `driver/modules/ipmitool.py` in which code (especially `_exec_ipmitool` func) resends IPMI command till timeout reaches (timeout default value is set to 60s in `conf/ipmi.py`). So every IPMI operation attempt takes 60s and then Redfish operation runs.
Changing default timeout value through `ironic.conf [ipmi] command_retry_timeout` affects another driver's IPMI operation. So changing timeout value to mitigate this delay is not good.

Such additional delay is bit hard thing, I think.
I think it's reasonable to have a method in the IPMI module that would not retry for this use case. Don't let yourself be limited by the methods that already exist.

So every sixty seconds is concerning.

As if you have say 1000 nodes, and it takes 3 seconds per node to check each node, and you have three conductors.

333.3 nodes per conductor
3 seconds per node
1000 seconds for each conductor to complete it's responsible list of nodes

Could we instead take a path of "check, and cache it when we know we need to" ? I think the verify step makes much more sense.

60 seconds is alarmingly too frequent.

For example, if you have 1000 nodes, and this step is to execute every sixty seconds, the odds of getting through nodes every sixty seconds is kind of unrealistic.

So essentially we'll end up constantly looping polling the firmware version, and most operators only change the version of the firmware maybe a couple times per year.

Could a better strategy be to check before and update the value if it is older than some period of time?

Just one suggestion that maybe it would be better to name them after each of the openstacksdk proxy services so that we don't have two clients called "neutron", "nova", etc. That will make it easier to migrate over individual resources. Yeah, I think the question is, do we want to just use a single client for all resources. So all resources would use default_client_name = openstack then we use the relevant service proxies based on that, like self.client().network. self.client().compute. self.client().object_store.  so using each service proxy off of the main underlying openstack client plugin. Or, would we rather implement individual service plugins like we have today, where we just return the connection for openstack.network as the client, or openstack.compute, openstack.object_store.
